name: Dual Duel Aradel - Build-a-Bear
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play. 

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion.  I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.  

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics - I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn. 

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn. 

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.  

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass:  Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through. 

Burn:  Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn. 

Mill:  Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it.  This forces the opponent into fatigue faster. 

——————————————————————————-
Style: Tall / Control

Pressure: Bypass

This deck is designed to control the opponents small units with Aradel’s ability, Nature’s Wrath and Ice Trap, and ping damage through Summon Gilder, Pain Shamans, and the Natural dice power while building up a large swing past the opponents board with some combination of Frostback Bear (with its Terrifying ability giving it evasion), Blue Jaguar (whose Gaze ability can prevent bigger units from blocking Frostback Bear or something else large), Massive Growth to make the unit huge, and Inflame to force the opponent to block something little instead of something big.  

Molten Gold is a good finishing blow for the deck if your Bear swings can get them down to 3 or less life, and can also function as a removal spell if needed. Change Psyche is a very flexible spell allowing you to either refresh your massive bear after it’s swung for another swing, or exhaust a big unit to get a bear past their board.  Lastly, Golden Veil is a must to protect your big threats from removal. 

Your first 5 should always include Summon Frostback Bear, Summon Blue Jaguar and Summon Gilder.  That, plus your Water Blast ability which you should try to use each round, costs 8 dice. Your last two cards should cost 1 die each and can vary based on the matchup.  Until you get used to the deck and the matchups, I’d suggest Summon Butterfly Monk and either Raptor Herder or Ice Trap.  These are going to be useful nearly all of the time, and opening with a Butterfly book ensures you have it all game.  Against Tristan Darkwater, Xander Heartsblood, Odette Diamondcrest and maybe Hope Everthorn, I might look at starting a Golden Veil to protect my units from their devastating unique spells.  Against an expected swarm, Nature’s Wrath is helpful. Getting used to the matchups will help you make these decisions going forward.  Do note that Massive Growth is a Chained card (a list of cards that, for organized play, are not allowed to be chosen in your First Five or played in Round 1.  Check the Plaid Hat Games Organized Play rules for a complete list of chained cards), so don’t choose that in your First Five.

notes:

—————————————————————

Style: Control

Pressure: Bypass / Burn

My first Dual Duelling deck using Scourge is here!  I wanted in Rin specifically for Shattering Fist, which I think is an amazing card that catapults Rin up the competitive ladder. 

The idea here is to control the board through your efficient removal in Adaptadon, Shattering Fist, Ice Trap, Gilder and Clashing Tempers. Try to target down specifically opposing units with 2+ attack so that your Frostback Bear + Mind Fog Owl can get through to face, hopefully with a Massive Growth or Wallop attached. 

Rin’s ability, Ice Buff, is key to the gameplay here. I normally like attaching Ice Buff to 1-life units as it doubles their life and seems to get the most value that way. However, this deck doesn’t have many of those. So instead, you’ll need to pay attention to the board state and use it where you can swing a trade into your favor by doing so.  Need to swing a bear into a 2-life 3/4 knight?  Here’s your chance to use Ice Buff.  It’s important that you use it every round though even if you can’t find that perfect trade, but keep your eyes peeled for it. 

First five is just the 4 books and a flex 1-die card based on matchup. Ice Trap, Raptor Herder, Wallop, and Shattering Fist all seem good here.

name: Dual Duel Maeoni - Ode to Biter
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Tall

Pressure: Bypass

I put Maeoni off for a bit in this series, even though she’s likely the simplest deck to choose 2 colors for.  I’ve played very, very little Maeoni in my Ashes life. That being said, there are still universal truths that I can apply to her and this deck, and the games I have played with Maeoni have been successful. 

In my opinion, you can’t really build Maeoni without building around Summon Silver Snake.  It’s just too good. So good that not including it as your focal point likely makes your deck worse.  So that’s where we start, and it locks us into Nature and Charm. The strategy is then simple - kill everything you can on their board to grow your snake until it’s ready to strike. 

Gilder is an auto-include in any Snake deck. It’s probably already the best Unit Guard in Ashes without its Inheritance ability even being useful in your deck, but here it’ll always have a use, and it’s ping on entry often boosts the Snake up. It’s in every first 5 every time with Snake. 

Frostback Bear is just so consistent that I had to include it.  I don’t know that you play it every game, but I would feel wrong to not have it here as an option.  Biter is another story though - this is a very cheeky include on my part, but I think an interesting one.  Maeoni’s Command Strike ability is very strong, but only if you have a unit with good attack on the board. Early on, if the opponent is able to remove Snake, there’s not a ton in these colors that will get Command Strike up over two, and especially not in the form of conjurations. Biter can come in for 2 dice on command (pun totally intended), allow you to immediately fire off Command Strike for 3. Just by having this book down, the opponent has to be extremely careful with putting 3 health units into the board, knowing that you can just Biter + Command Strike if you want to.  This pairs really well with the 3x Ice Trap to deal with smaller stuff.  It’s also excellent for the same reason with Seeds of Aggression, and there it’s lower 2 life is a bit of a benefit because sometimes you need to clear up battlefield space for another unit. And it’s a Unit Guard, and Snake is your attacking threat anyway so you don’t really need to swing.  For all those reasons (and the fact that I’m just playing these two colors), I think Biter has a home here. 

Hypnotize is just a way to get your Snake into face if you run into a wall you can’t clear out. 

Frost Fang and Beast Tamer are a couple of techy ally choices here.  Frost Fang can replace Biter in a first five where you feel like you need to go a bit faster.  Beast Tamer provides an Alert unit, which I think is very important in decks with small battlefields to maximize the efficiency of each battlefield slot. 

This deck is very dice power side hungry, and these colors have no dice fixing, so I think Call Upon the Realms x3 is a must. Nature’s Wrath x3 is also a must - the deck needs AoE to handle swarms, and it has the side benefit of helping with self-clear and boosting the Snek up as well. 

Root Armor is a key card to keeping the Snake alive and growing. It’s SO much harder to kill a Snake with armor on it. 

The Golden Veils are going to be a staple in any Tall deck to protect your threat, so you get 3 here. The 1x Call to Action is a cheeky include - when it’s in hand sometimes you can get a really big refresh on Snake when they think you’re holding Veil instead and it’s a huge blowout. And if it gets medded into the discard, now the opponent sees that and will be much more tentative with their attacks when you have a Snake die showing, so you get indirect benefit. For that reason (and to bluff Veil), try to keep a Snake die showing as often as you can. Redirect is another great use for that Snake die, helping with self-clear and the small battlefield. 

First Five always has Snake and Gilder. From there, you’ve got options.  Biter/Frost Fang/Beast Tamer + Root Armor + Golden Veil + Command Strike is one good one. Frostback Bear + Golden Veil + Hypnotize + Command Strike is another.  You can forego Command Strike altogether in round 1 and go Bear, Biter / Beast Tamer, Veil.  I think they’re all good and it’s going to depend on what you’re up against.  If you’re up against a swarm (maybe Hope or James), the last one with a Tamer and no Command Strike might be best.  If you up against Echo in time/illusion, I think I’d go with Frost Fang + Command Strike to try and deal with an opening Realm Walker.  Against others, the first one might be the way to go.

name: Dual Duel Saria - Passive Aggression
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Control

Pressure: Mill

Welcome to Saria’s dinner party, where all the passive aggressive banter one could ever wish for will ensue!

This deck is all about controlling your opponent until they get tired and start taking fatigue damage.  Of all the DD decks, this is probably the most advanced so far. I’d recommend playing a few of the other Control style decks before picking this one up. 

The idea here is to use Light Bringer and Seaside Raven to keep your opponents units under control, while Cobra and Saria’s Hearts Pull ability keep on a steady stream of discarding your opponents deck. Three-Eyed Owl is great for this as well - it provides a lot of extra discard pressure, especially when it’s summoned later in the round. That’s kind of a theme to this deck which makes it a bit tougher to pilot I think - the timing and sequencing of each of these summon books can be tough.  LB wants to exhaust a prime target. Cobra wants to make sure it swings and, ideally, survives to keep on the pressure. Owl needs to live through the end of the round, and Raven doesn’t want to come down until there’s something juicy to eat. 

Even though it’s not a mill card, Raven is very important to the deck. Not only is it a great control card, but it eats up 3 basic dice.  It’s a great way to spend those without having to meditate, and since we’re a fatigue deck, we want to meditate as little as possible.  We also want to play as few cards from hand as possible, so being able to spend 3 dice per round that don’t need to be meditated and don’t cost a card from our deck is big.  Its problem is Ice Trap - that card just blows Raven out. There is a Veil in here for Round 1 if you’re certain it’s coming, but after that you’ve got to be very careful about when you summon Raven. Try to bait out ice trap with Cobra and Owl if you can - this will be easier to do later in the game when the opponent is afraid of those cards because they don’t want to get milled. 

The action spells in here are all good, but you need to be very careful playing them. Every one played is another card gone, and we’re trying to be ahead on cards.  Call Upon the Realms might be an exception since it’ll save you 2 cards if you spin up 3 dice that you needed to spin up anyway, but again make sure you need those dice.  Also Return to Soil is usually always a good play if you can kill something with it, since that goes even on cards with your opponent and works as removal.

Saria’s 5 battlefield can be an issue with so many books and allies, so the deck has a bunch of self-clear spells.  The trick here is getting value out of your units before you clear them out for new, fresh ones. Meteor is obviously the most powerful - this is either a good reset button to slow down the game, or can be one-sided if you can get value out of your units early and then Meteor the board before they get to use theirs.  Kneel is very similar in this regard, but only lasts the round. Seeds of Aggression is great for use on an exhausted Seaside Raven - try to kill something with 2AV or more if your Raven book is unexhausted, so your Raven dies and you can summon a new one. Lastly, Rally the Troops is a cheeky spell that will surprise an opponent and punish them for not clearing off your exhausted Violinists or Shepherds, allowing you to use them again AND heal. 

Speaking of the allies, they’re a toolbox to supplement the spellboard, much like the action spells are. Be careful with them just like the spells.  Ninja is a really cool round 1 card - dropping this early creates a lot of pressure, and the opponent will almost never want to discard a first five card, so if he swings he almost always gets to mill 2.  Beast Tamer is your best Frostback Bear blocker and also your best counter to little guys like Fallen. Flock Shepherd works well to keep your cobras and owls safe so they get to survive rounds and get value from their abilities. Violinist is just like Soil - goes even on cards, adds mill pressure and leaves a body behind that they either have to remove or face it again, or it’s there for Seeds or Rally.  Shepherd enables the deck to run 1-2 of each of these and grab whichever you need from the discard for the situation. 

Lastly Redirect does a few good things. It provides protection against a big swing from Snake, a Massive Growthed Bear, or a big Fighting Spirit attack.  It also functions as a pseudo-healing spell and a self-clear spell wrapped into one. Very nice spell for the deck. 

The first five for this deck is a bit tough. I’d say it’s usually Raven, Light Bringer, Cobra, Ninja, Beast Tamer, Hearts Pull.  You can start an Owl book if you want, and then either hope to draw into a one-die card with Hearts Pull, or just use a dice power. But you have 3 Owl books so if you don’t open it, you have good odds to draw into it Round 2 and get them going.  If you’re really scared of Ice Trap in round 1, you can start Golden Veil instead of one of the allies and again either use a dice power or get lucky on the Hearts Pull draw.

name: Dual Duel Leo - Finch Up
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

——————————————————————————-

Style: Control

Pressure: Mill

This deck is a “turbo-mill” deck partly inspired by TheTreatment.  The idea here is to just empty your opponents deck as quickly as possible.  You attack their deck with Doves and Glow Finch, along with Return to Soil, Remorse, Imperial Ninja and Violinists. You attack there hand with Owls and Anguish, with accomplishes the same thing as they’ll have to draw more at the beginning of the round.  You end the game by using Summon Orchid Dove and Abundance to deal damage directly to the Phoenixborn if their deck is empty, and also by Fatigue damage, not to mention you’re removing their options by discarding cards from their hand and deck. 

Be very careful about meditating from deck - you really don’t want to lose Abundance or Dove books as the Focus 2 effects are big for the deck. Meditate from hand whenever possible. If you want to go to 3 colors, adding in Sympathy for Essence Druid or Time for Recollect can help with this, but in these colors there’s no way to get any lost cards back, so meditate as little as possible. This deck uses very few Power dice for costs (just the four reaction spells, and you have 9 charm dice to roll those Power sides), and a lot of basic costs once Orchid Dove is focused, so hopefully you don’t need to meditate often. This also helps you stay ahead of your opponent in cards, which you should always be monitoring when playing a mill deck. You need to be able to outlast your opponent. 

Speaking of that, Generosity is an all-star card in this deck. Playing it can heal your Phoenixborn for 2, which helps extend the game.  However, oftentimes your opponent won’t have any damage on their Phoenixborn since you aren’t attacking them. Therefore if you’re not low on life, it might be better to choose the Unexhaust option first, refreshing either Abundance or Leo himself to get another Glow Finch if the one you summoned this round is dead already. They are then stuck with choosing heal, which doesn’t help them, or draw 3, which advances your win condition.  And if they allow to draw, that helps you get your Abundance and Dove spells focused. 

As this deck doesn’t run many units with more than 1 attack value, Terrifying units like Frostback Bear or Shining Hydra can bypass your birds easily.  To counter this, you’ve got 3 Flock Shepherds to allow your 0-attack birds to block bears and also be protected from targeted ping. Additionally, Redirect can both save you from a big bypass swing and also self-kill a bird to mill your opponent more. Lastly, Beast Tamer is a very difficult to kill unit that can block something with Terrifying 1. 

First Five should include the three ready spells, and Imperial Ninja as he’ll almost always mill the opponent for two in round 1. Your fifth card can go a lot of ways. Anguish if you think you’re against another slow deck, Beast Tamer for swarms. Violinist for weenies, etc.  Even if you start another 2-die ally, you’ll have a couple dice left over that can either be used on cards drawn with Abundance or on Charm dice powers to slow down the opponents opening units.

name: Dual Duel Lulu - Pact of Pinging
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Control

Pressure: Burn

I’ve always liked playing Lulu as a nature / ceremony deck - she feels very comfortable with a burn package thanks to her unique Phoenix Barrage, and that strategy was only helped by Chant of Transfusion. 

Emberoot Lizard functions somewhat as a secondary Lulu unique card, as it combos very well with her Spark ability. Frostback Bear is another great use of Spark though, so don’t always default directly to putting it on the lizard. 

This deck benefits from a bit of healing as well with Butterflies and Phoenix Attendant. Lulu needs it at 16 life, and it slots in nicely with the rest of the burn package. 

Other than that, it’s a pretty simple list. Run the burn cards in the colors. 3 Old Salt because they’re amazing and perfect with Transfusion. Ice traps because they’re awesome and Natures Wrath because it’s awesome. One Raptor Herder to include in the first five if you want it.  Try to apply early pressure while playing burn spells - Phoenix Barrage is amazing because it does both. 

First five is probably the 3 books, Ritualist and Raptor Herder / Ice Trap. Spark the Lizard or the Bear.  You can also open with Old Salt instead of the Herder if you skip either Spark or the Butterfly.

name: Dual Duel Rimea - Ritualist Rimea List
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Control

Pressure: Burn

Rimea is one of the harder Phoenixborn to pilot for sure. In that vein, I’ve given her a bit of a simple deck to try and play.  It’s easy to get caught up in using her ability, Visions, and basing a deck around that. But this list is really all about her 20 life and her unique, Ancestral Army. 

Army is the only card in the game that lets you put 3 blockers on the board in one main action.  Burn decks often struggle because they spend cards and dice doing direct Phoenixborn damage and not playing to the board.  Army helps alleviate that, allowing Rimea to put out a bunch of units efficiently and still have cards and dice left over to play burn spells. 

That being said, Visions is still very useful. It can be used before summoning Ancestral Army to setup your draws off of Ancestor Spirits.  Also, these burn spells and butterflies cost power dice, and you’ll be using ceremonial power dice to recur Armies. You’ll need to meditate for those, but using Visions early in the round will allow you to control what cards you meditate away to an extent. Make use of that - if you aren’t taking a side action, you should be using Visions. Note that Rimea doesn’t exhaust unless you spend a die to move a card to the bottom, which you should basically never do. 

Chant of Revenge is a big burn engine for you. You want 2 down in round 1 and to try  to get them to fire each round. You’ve got a bunch of self-kill options to make this happen if you need to.  Bear is as solid a summon spell as you can find, and Butterfly Monk can be used to extend that already high life total when needed, or offset the cost of using the ceremonial die power. 

I’ve already discussed Ancestral Army.  Ritualist goes into the first five to double up your revenge in round 1. Fire Archer is the best burn spell because it comes with a body, too.  Crimson Bomber does triple duty as a high attack unit, an AoE spell and a way to turn on your own chants. 

Molten Gold is one of the best burn spells and the preferred finisher of the deck. Blood Chains is excellent hard removal and also can turn on chants and/or fire off Final Cry for more burn.  Clashing Tempers is great with the three units provided with Ancestral Army, and helps out Bomber and Nature’s Wrath with crowd control.  Rimea’s 4 BF can sometimes make dealing with an opposing wide board difficult, but with bombers, wrath and tempers, hopefully Rimea can keep it in check. Lastly, as I said above there will be lots of meditation and tanking damage - Channel Magic can help with that. Also, it draws a card, so you can use Visions as your side action first to draw the card you want. 

Lastly, Final Cry is pretty self-explanatory here, and there’s 1 Ice Trap in case you want to flex it into a first five against something scary, like maybe Adaptadon. 

First five here is typically Bear, Butterfly, Chant, Ritualist (grab second chant), Ancestral Army.  That’s 6 units, so you either need to naturally trade some off, or pivot away from summoning a butterfly and into a frog ping to either self-kill your Ritualist or use it against the opponent.

name: Dual Duel Harold - Candyman Candyman Candyman
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics  I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

——————————————————————————-

Style: Control

Pressure: Burn

The idea of this deck is to dominate the battlefield through Harold’s Mary Prey ability taking down big threats, Old Salt coming in with damage and being a great attacker (especially when combined with Mark Prey), Chant of Transfusion ping damage, Master Vampires stalking important targets, Mirror Spirit potentially exhausting units once it is focused, and Consume Soul allowing resets of Mark Prey.  You win by getting damage through their empty board and finishing off with burn damage from Fire Archers, Final Cry and Sympathy Pain. 

This deck also has a large amount of Phoenixborn healing with Master Vampire, Consume Soul and Phoenix Attendant. Phoenix Attendant combos with Chant of Transfusion exceptionally well. The healing is important because control decks need to be patient - they want to incrementally gain advantage over time by eliminating the opponents board and slowly building up a dominating battlefield, so Harold needs to survive a while to do that. 

Mirror Spirit is a very large threat against the opponent here. When you build up that dominating board, there are often times where your opponents board is close to empty and yours has 4-5 exhausted guys on it. This is when Mirror Spirit comes out for big damage.  This makes it advantageous for you to use your units to destroy theirs but survive, sitting there exhausted to pump your late round Mirror Spirit. That means you should be actively looking for opportunities to use Hunters Mark and Stalk on the Master Vampire to eliminate your opponents units while keeping yours alive.  Mirror Spirit also pairs nicely with Salamander Monk, as the opponent is likely to want to leave a Salamander exhausted, because destroying it will allow the Spirit to come out and give you another blocker. And even if the spirit does come out, you can always just attack with it for 0 later in the round to exhaust it and boost up your Mirror Spirit anyway. 

Blood Chains is an excellent card in this deck to not only lock down big threats, but also potentially power up your Mirror Spirits and turn on your Chants of Transfusion and Final Cries. Plus the beefy units in here give good opportunities for the double-exhaust effect of Blood Chains. 

The 1x Rapture in here is a panic button. If you’re getting overwhelmed with little units, sometimes this card can be a life saver. 

The first five here is normally Summon Salamander Monk, Summon Mirror Spirit, Ritualist (to search out and play Chant of Transfusion), Old Salt and Master Vampire. That uses up all 10 dice.  If you expect your opponent to come out with a big threat, you’ll want to deploy the Vampire early to combat it.

name: Dual Duel Tristan - Fish Fry
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

——————————————————————————-

Style: Wide

Pressure: Burn

This Tristan list is very similar to the Fish Fry deck that my son played this year at Gen Con to go 3-1 and take 4th place. The idea here is to attack hard and fast with a swarm of units that have the Group Tactics ability, which when combined with Tristan’s Magnify ability can sling out a ton of damage quickly. Prism Tetra, Vampire Bats, Raptor Herder / Hatchling and Beast Warriors all have this ability and can swarm the board very fast. Once you punch through quickly with wide swings, you can finish off with burn spells to deal the remaining damage to the PB, but you also have Mirror Spirit to come in towards the end of the round as a heavy hitter. 

I really like the synergy between Prism Tetra and Mirror Spirit. Because the Tetra kill themselves at the end of the round, the opponent oftentimes doesn’t want to block them with non 0-attack units, because there’s no need to be able to counter and kill them. Mirror Spirit punishes them for that, as it gets stronger the more exhausted units that are on the board.  If the opponent is keeping your units under control, you also have Blood Chains to exhaust their units instead, and use their exhaustion for Mirror Spirit. 

Dark Reaping provides some dice fixing if needed, but it’s here even more for being able to self-trigger Final Cry and Summon Sleeping Widows, as you want to be as proactive with your burn as you can be. As a side action, it’s especially good with Widows as you can blow up an exhausted Tetra or something, react with Widows and swing right away for an unexpected 4 damage coming in.  If you don’t like Dark Reaping, it can be switched out of the list for Crescendo, which can still self-trigger those spells (though not at side action speed) and provides more removal. 

The 1x Choke can be a cheeky first five card against someone like Coal, who will draw a bunch of cards and slash down your weak units. It’s also great late game against Jessa and just generically useful in other places, if for nothing else than a 1 damage burn spell. 

Lastly, Tsunami Shot is one of the best cards in the game. It’s basically never bad and is super flexible as removal for either tall or wide units. 

Your first five probably always includes the 3 books and Magnify, which is 7 dice. You can spend the last 3 on something like Tsunami Shot and either Raptor Herder or Choke. You could also go more all-out on units and go Raptor and Beast Warrior, and then plan to try and spend a die to respawn the Vampire Bats once.  Ideally, try to hang onto the Mirror Spirit book until later in the round to hide it from the opponents knowledge and surprise them with a big hitter.  If your board gets cleared, as long as you save a ceremonial and a sympathy die to use on it, you can always pivot instead to using the Ceremonial power to recur a Raptor Herder and then replay it instead of summoning the Mirror Spirit if it wouldn’t be doing much. But you want to get that Mirror Spirit book down in round 1, as if it’s Focus ability comes online in round 2, it can be great for exhausting out big alert units so you can swing through them.

name: Dual Duelling Orrick - Chant of Vitality
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Control

Pressure: Burn

This deck is all about healing and delaying until Orrick wakes up.   I’m going to preface this by saying I think the deck is a lot better with some nature dice to add in Summon Butterfly Monk and Root Armor, so when you’re ready to go to 3 colors and you’ve seen which cards you like the least here, I suggest that swap. Light Bringer is the first card to go, and I think you want 3x Butterfly books.  From there, cut what feels like you use it the least, but probably not from the spellboard. 

The main combo centers around Phoenix Attendant, Chant of Transfusion and Drain Vitality. That’s your engine - try to continually use this combo to heal and ping and just abuse it as much as possible.  Ritualist helps get the chants going while giving you a body to fuel them, and Shepherd just gets back your Attendants, or your Ritualist to go get another chant. 

The action spells are just to heal you more. Reclaim Soul has the added benefit of activating your Chants if they aren’t already. 

Law of Fear is like, the ultimate “slow down the game” card.  You want to play it in round 1 against anything you feel might be at all aggressive on the battlefield. 

Concentration is your win condition.  You need to focus it, so be careful not to lose 2 of them. This deck should almost never need to meditate more than one per round between Concentration fixing dice and only being 2 colors, and Orrick’s ability can get you back the card you lost. You should med that 1 per round at least every round just to get an extra card pull with Orrick, but hopefully not more than that.  Heal and slow the game down until focused Concentration is online, which won’t take that long since you’re drawing at least 2 extra cards per round.  Once that’s online, your ping damage just gets crazy and you’ll start burning the opponent out. 

My constructed list for this actually also splashes a Charm die for 3x Golden Veil to protect the Attendant. I don’t have that here, so I had to settle for Angelic Rescue.  This won’t protect against hard removal though like Fester or Fade Away. So again if you’re comfortable, I recommend a 1x Charm splash just to get access to Golden Veil. Again with Orrick’s ability and Concentration, dice fixing usually isn’t an issue. 

Your First Five here is Concentration, Light Bringer, Ritualist, Phoenix Attendant, Law of Fear / Drain Vitality.  Law of Fear if you think they’re gonna play battlefield threats, and Vitality if they’re some kind of mill deck.  You’ll get 2 extra cards with Orrick’s ability and Concentration that you’ll likely be able to play with your leftover dice. Also consider using the Ceremonial Power to recur and replay the Ritualist it it’s killed.

name: Dual Duel Brennen - Bounce to the Heavens
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Control

Pressure: Bypass

I decided to go the Change of Heart route with the DD Brennen. I think the burn decks that use Spirit Burn have very thin margins of error. This deck should be a bit more forgiving. 

The deck wants to control the board with its allies, leveraging the enter the battlefield effects of cards like Anchornaut, Old Salt, Polarity Mage and Shepherd of Lost Souls to create insane value on top of the ping damage from Change of Heart recycling them.  Shepherd is especially important, and she will help recycle your allies from the discard and make sure you have a steady stream of them. 

Fire Archer is just a little bit of burn and reach, but even at 1x it can be impactful when recycled.  Ritualist is to get your Chants online. Light Swordsman is amazing here - drop him and swing right away and, if they don’t kill him, you get to pick him up and do it again!  Grave Knight can be a surprise turn 1, and is also a really nice control card in some circumstances.  Use Polarity Mage to get your Change if Hearts back if you lose them from meditating. 

Light Bringer and Lioness are just additional divine control tools that you can have on tap every round.  Chant of Transfusion is great with the Old Salts, Attendants and Lionesses to generate more ping. 

You have some healing in the deck as well with Attendant, Heal and Channel Magic. Brennen will be happy to have that with their 16 life.  Fester is needed to deal with armored stuff where the pings won’t work. Sneak a wound on with Transfusion and then Fester. It’s also amazing on non-armored Knights alongside Change of Heart. You don’t need the frogs in this deck to get the pings. 

Add on Meteor and Rapture for some crowd control and bounce your way to victory!

First Five is Ritualist, Light Bringer, Lioness, Anchornaut, Change of Heart.  You’ll have a couple dice left to recur / replay an ally, or get both chants out in round 1 by playing Ritualist twice.  Could swap in Old Salty for the Anchornaut as well.

name: Dual Duel Dimona - A Different Reanimation
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Control

Pressure: Bypass

I wanted to do something a bit different with this Dimona - I think the current most competitive version of Dimona is a Fallen build. Check out nosuchmethod’s Dimona that won a recent tournament.  That’s a 3-color list with Charm for Open Memories and Divine for stuff like Shepherd of Lost Souls, and both of those are needed. If you want to run a 2-color Dimona Fallen, you could port most or all of the James Dual Duel list into Dimona and try that. 

Instead of Fallen, I’m punishing the opponent for killing my allies with Chant of Transfusion. If they kill them, I get Chant tokens. If they don’t, then I get Empyrean Mounts.  That’s the basic gist of the deck, apart from Resummon, which is my favorite pet Dimona card. I love attacking with an Empyrean Mount, forcing something with 2 attack to block it, surviving, then Resummoning the Mount to get a fresh one and the ally back into hand to be used again. It’s one of my favorite plays in all of Ashes.  

False Demon rounds out the spellboard as a consistently good book that can help trigger your chants by self-killing an exhausted ally if you want, or do more damage to the opponent. It also helps to have a use for basic dice on the spellboard. 

The allies are the meat of the deck, and playing them well will make or break it. Anchornaut is typically just a first five card, but helps in a pinch later. Remember you can attack with him to get him exhausted so he can mount up. Bomber is a nice AoE tool and self-turns on chants.  Fire Archer is the main ally you want to be using to mount, but Anchornaut works well, too.  Old Salt is a staple in any Chant of Transfusion list, as is Phoenix Attendant. Attendant is especially helpful with Dimona’s low life.  Rayward Knight is an excellent ally to keep your deck healthy, and also to attack into something with 2 or less attack to survive with wounds. Ritualist is just there to grab a Chant in round 1, but you can mount up with her so she comes back to grab more chants. 

Blood Brawl is a really great card here. Empyrean Mount and Rayward Knight are both excellent at attacking units and surviving the encounter with a wound or two. Combine that with Old Salts and Attendants sounding themselves, and Blood Brawl starts to look excellent.  Same goes for Blood Chains - it’s very easy to get the double exhaustion in this list.  Lastly, since you want your guys to be hanging around with damage on them, I leaned heavy into the ping protection spells with 3x each Particle Shield and Fate Reflection.  Keep those guys alive to either recover at the end of the round, or unleash the big Blood Brawl or Blood Chains.  I also added in a cheeky Calamity Golem - this guy can be a blowout in some situations, especially with the Rayward Knights and Attendants in here being good targets for him. 

Again remember, this is another control deck that wants to eliminate the opponents units and then swing through. Use your Mounts to eliminate key targets and hopefully survive, and send your Knights with their Charge ability into units the same way.  Don’t be too tempted to swing at the Phoenixborn if there are guys to kill. 

First five has some options, but I like Ritualist, Resummon, Demon, Fire Archer, Anchornaut.  With Chant, that’s 6 dice before you use Resummon. Now you’ll have flexibility in how you spend the last 4 dice. You can Mount + Resummon, or you can Mount + Ceremonial Power / replay an ally, or you can Ceremonial Power / replay an ally + Resummon the False Demon. See how the round goes and do whatever works best for the situation, with the default plan being Mount + Resummon unless it doesn’t work out that way.

name: Dual Duel James - Death Pact
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style:  Control / Wide

Pressure:  Bypass

This James deck is very simple and sticks almost to one color - it wants to play allies and have them die, fueling your Summon Fallen books and Chants of Transfusion to create a ton of value from two of the best value engines in Ashes. 

Fallen are the most efficient unit in the game.  They’re strong enough to dip into Charm for one die, just really for Open Memories in order to go and get a second Fallen book in round 1.  You want two books online before your allies start dying to max out the value.  James can use his ability to fuel allies to the board to keep the tokens coming. 

There’s a little bit of an ally toolbox here. I like having one Anchornaut to pull out in a pinch or in round 1. Old Salt is just a beast and great with Chant of Transfusion. Phoenix Attendant is likely the all-star - its combo potential with Chant of Transfusion is excellent. The same goes for Blood Archer, which also takes advantage of the Charm splash. 

Crimson Bomber is a great unit to get some AoE damage, and also self-kills to fuel the Fallen and Chants.  Ritualist is a must to get the Chants online early, and Rising Horde is good value for 2 dice, easily searchable for James, and combos nicely with Vengeance, allowing itself to blow up into 2 more attackers. 

Speaking of Vengeance, that’s the preferred way to win the game. Ideally, you use your Uber-efficient Fallen and Chant engine to thin out their board until you get to the beginning of a round where you go first.  You can side action Vengeance, hopefully blowing up a Rising Horde or two and maybe another ally, react with Summon Sleeping Widows, and then swing in for massive damage. Even without that play, Vengeance into Widows is a big surprise attack just by itself, especially if a Horde is destroyed. 

The 1x Choke is really just there maybe for Coal or Jessa to turn off their annoying abilities.  Blood Chains is a good hard removal spell which also triggers your Fallen books and Chants. 

First five - I’d suggest Summon Fallen, Open Memories (grab a second Fallen book), Ritualist, Blood Chains, Old Salt.  Use James’ ability to get another Ritualist to pull another Chant, or just grab the Anchornaut to ping something. You should have 1 or 2 ceremonial dice left to play Fallen depending on whether you went Ritualist + Chant #2, or Anchornaut, and you’ll be guaranteed at least one token on the books thanks to Blood Chains killing an ally if your opponent doesn’t take out an ally for you. 

EDIT:  this list should be 3x Blood Chains and 2x Crimson Bomber

name: Dual Duel Koji - Fallen Wolves
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Control

Pressure: Bypass

This deck attempts to win through sheer efficiency. Fallen and Wolfpack Leader are among the most efficient units in the game, and together they guarantee a bunch of free 1/1s, and these can be used to out-trade the opponent by killing their units they actually have to spend dice on. 

The ally suite is the backbone of the deck, and is crafted of units that the opponent really wants to get rid of or, in Old Salt’s case, has removal on play.  Beast Tamer, Blood Archer, Iron Worker and Wolfpack Leader all demand a response, otherwise you get a lasting benefit.  And if they do kill them, you get zombies. 

Blood Chains and Reclaim Soul can force the issue if they try to avoid killing your allies, while still providing you with benefits. Open Memories is solely for the first five to make sure two Fallen Books are setup immediately. 

Lastly, Koji’s low life makes him susceptible to big bypass swings or burn, so the Redirects help with that, along with serving as another way to kill your own allies and accrue fallen tokens. And if you want your guys to die, you might as well make some spiders. 

If you’re ready for a third color, this deck really benefits from Guilt Link in Sympathy, as Koji can use his ability to turn it on without needing to be attacked.  Without that, Koji’s ability is best on Wolfpack Leader here, but can also be used on a Fallen book. 

First five is Fallen, Open Memories (second Fallen book), Bone Crow, Wolfpack Leader and Blood Chains. The remaining 3 dice should be a ceremonial power to resurrect Wolfpack Leader and play it again.

name: Dual Duel Jessa - Turtle Soup
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.
