Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Control

Pressure: Burn

Jessa is, IMO, just one of the coolest Phoenixborn in the game, and I tried for an old-school Jessa vibe here.  This deck wants to control the game with efficient units, using Screams of the Departed when they die, slowly whittling the opponent down while Jessa stays healthy with healing. 

Jessa is one of the few Phoenixborn with a Pressure point built into her ability, so we don’t have to really run many cards to apply non-battlefield pressure. Final Cry sneaks into the list really just because there are so many self-kill spells here to activate it. 

Turtle Guard and Snapper are both great Jessa units. Snapper helps her manage her 4 battlefield by wiping out exhausted wishing wings or other turtles, and Turtle Guard provides a great unit guarder, excellent synergy with Chant of Transfusion and Blood Chains, and it also has 1 Recover, making it a great unit to use with Fear, as Jessa will heal 1. 

The allies are all high in synergy as well, particularly with Chant of Transfusion.  I went heavy on Ritualists because I think it’s important to get a lot of chants out fast.  Old Salt is just a beast. Phoenix attendant is an all-star, comboing with Chant for healing and damage, and is another fantastic Blood Chains and Fear Target. Bomber gives the deck a little bit of AoE and more self-clear.  Crypt Guardian helps even up the battlefield size discrepancy when he survives the round. 

Reclaim Soul is just more healing and self-kill to open battlefield, trigger chants and activate Screams. Fate Reflection rounds out the deck with some protection for your important units. 

The last thing I’ll say is be careful about when you scream. A lot of times, you don’t need to scream a lot early - just organically get some damage through with attacks and final cry, and then start screaming to close out the game. But it’s always there as a way to spend dice that you can’t utilize in a given round. Play around with it some and soon you’ll have a good feel for when it’s good to scream and when it’s not. 

First five here is likely the 3 books, Ritualist and either Crypt Guardian or Fear. If it’s Fear, plan to use a Ceremonial Power to recur the Ritualist and replay it, getting out a second Chant in round 1.

name: Dual Duelling Jericho - Horse Swag
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Tall / Wide

Pressure: Bypass

For this Jericho, I went back to the past a bit.  The first Ashes Reborn deck my son ever built was a Jericho list he called “Swag Status Up” that was based on Squall Stallion and Time Hopper. He took it to a local meetup we had at a store near us back then, and cleaned up pretty well even though he had no real Ashes experience.  So Jericho + Stallion holds a bit of a soft spot in my heart. 

The idea here is that Summon Squall Stallion draws a card on activation, meaning that Jericho’s Prepare ability to search her deck for a card and put it on top can be combined with Stallion to always put that card right into hand.  The Time Hoppers then can feed tokens to the horse, and Jericho can Prepare a second Hopper book in round 1 to focus them immediately and make sure you’ve got Rabbits for days. 

When my son built the deck, he didn’t have Fighting Spirit as it wasn’t printed yet, so he used Hypnotize and charm dice to threaten a big horse swing. But now, Fighting Spirit is here to let our Hoppers throw tokens everywhere and give us multiple different Tall threats throughout the game, and we can use Stand Still as the bypass tool instead. Fighting Spirit is nice here as our two books put tokens into the board, and we’ve got more token generators in Standard Bearer, Ocean’s Gift and even Radiant Leviathan. 

If you noticed, I listed the style as “Tall / Wide, which is a little weird.  However, that’s because we do have multiple Tall threats in Squall Stallions growing organically through their ability and extra Hopper tokens, and also Fighting Spirit being able to turn any unit into a big threat after some time.  But sometimes you can make wise swings with lots of Hoppers + Standard Bearer, and potentially a Radiant Leviathan that explodes into a bunch of fish. I think your main win con though should be a tall bypass finishing blow, and more often than not you’ll want to send your hoppers one at a time into units instead, but be on the lookout for a wide swing opportunity where you don’t leave yourself open for retaliation. 

Speaking of Leviathan, it’s a really cool card in here for a lot of reasons. First, all of our Bunnies could mean that Leviathan comes into play with a bunch of tokens on it. That’s both good for charging Fighting Spirit and for leaving a bunch of Prism Tetra behind when it dies. Those fish might not seem like a huge deal, but remember that Fighting Spirit can make it swing hard. Also, River Skalds love to yeet Whale spells at opposing knights for 4 damage, and Jericho can set this up with Prepare, so that you draw the Whale spell with River Skald’s ability. 

The rest of the cards are tools for situations that can be pulled out when needed. Note that Blink is bad with Stallion and Leviathan as it will remove the tokens from them, so that’s why there’s only 2. But it’s still good to reset some units (Raptor Herder is great) or as a bypass tool to remove an opponents unit before you swing. Seeds gives you a bit of self-clear, which this deck lacks a bit as these colors aren’t great for it. Crescendo helps there, too along with providing more bypass, and Fate Reflection can save a big horse that would die. Lastly, 1x Accelerate to pull out that big combo turn, and Generosity to draw cards and fuel your horses. 

If you’re interested in going into a 3rd color, look to Nature. Root Armor, Hunt Master, Natures Wrath and Explosive Growth would all be great additions here. 

First 5 is probably Stallion, Hopper, Fighting Spirit, Raptor Herder, Generosity. Prepare a second Hopper book and draw it with the horse. Generosity early to draw 3 to fuel your horse and so they can’t heal or unexhaust.

name: Dual Duel Coal - Time to Cut a Fool
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Control

Pressure: Bypass

This list feels a bit more straightforward maybe than others, but that what these decks are for!  The idea here is to put out a ton of efficient weenies and trade favorably into your opponents units, all while pumping up your Fighting Spirits to constantly threaten a massive swing. 

Wishing Wing is the star here. You always want to be putting these down, and probably following that up with a Time Hopper summon to boost it.  Then you have a 2/1 that charges Fighting Spirit when it dies and also draws you 2 cards, which Coal can turn into more damage. 

We should probably talk about Coal here - Slash is an extremely powerful ability, and you can’t be afraid to use it. Your rule of thumb should be that if you can’t play or aren’t going to play a card in a given round, you should discard it to Slash. Wishing Wing is going to draw you a bunch of cards to allow Slashes (as is 100 Blades and Particle Shield), and if you don’t plan on putting them onto the board, you should slash them at the opponents board. Your wincon is to eliminate the opponents board and swing through it, so use Slash to do that.  This deck will burn brightly and fast though - be aggressive!!

Oceans Gift is a really nice card both for dice fixing and token generation, as well as giving an attack boost. One of the all-stars of the deck. 

The allies aren’t needed much here, but they each can be great in the right situation - use them wisely. 

Particle Shield is really nice to save one of your small units from a ping or 1-die attack, and draw a card that Coal can slash with. Additionally, Flash Strike is the ultimate trade-up card, or is just great for 2 damage on the PB if your guy gets through.  Double Down is excellent on Wishing Wings to continue that engine (make sure you have a Time power die showing so the new wishing wings get their boost when they enter play), but can also be good on Time Hoppers to throw a bunch of status tokens around and get 2 new, unexpected attackers. 

Also, just like Slash, don’t be afraid to use Fighting Spirit each round. It’s true that it will reduce it down and stop charging, but many times it’s more important to use it as a tool to trade up into a bigger threat. Also, remember it puts a token on the unit, so it will boost the wishing wings up further and can be used to get a token onto a demon or something so that it charges Fighting Spirit or can use Flash Strike.  False Demon is nice here as a basic sink and it’s great for clearing out exhausted Wishing Wings to draw cards, or exhausted Time Hoppers to make room for more units.  Or you know, it can just be more ping damage to clear opposing units out. 

Lastly, you’re going to have a bunch of little bodies running around, but remember this isn’t a wide deck. This is a control deck that builds up to one big strike. You want to eliminate the opponents board first, so try to direct most or all of your attacks at enemy units instead of at the Phoenixborn. Try to find situations where you’re attacking a 2 or 3 dice unit with your 1-die unit and threatening to kill it, or even just take it down to 1 life, knowing that a Slash can finish it off. This will put immense pressure on your opponents Phoenixborn to use their one guard for the round, giving you free rein to go to town on their units and clear the way for the big Fighting Spirit swing. 

First five is almost always going to be the 3 books, Fighting Spirit and Gates Thrown Open.

name: Dual Duel Noah - Reaction Time
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

——————————————————————————-

Style: Tall

Pressure: Bypass

This Noah deck is designed to use its plentiful cheap, but efficient units with status tokens to out-trade the opponent while building up tokens on Fighting Spirit to eventually get through with a couple large, Fighting Spirit boosted swings to end the game, probably assisted by a Realm Walker or by casting Stand Still to prevent an opposing unit from blocking. This is accomplished by using Wishing Wing as a cheap, but very threatening unit due to its attack value scaling to the number of tokens on it. The opponent is often forced to kill these before they get too big, but that charges up your Fighting Spirit spells and draws you cards, helping you to find your additional Wishing Wing and Time Hopper books to just keep the pressure coming. And if they don’t kill them, attack with them yourself, trading up into more expensive units, and then use the Hungry Seafoam Snapper to kill them yourself. 

The deck has a lot of additional card draw with Shadowblade, Accelerate, Excavate and Particle Shield. Along with helping you focus your Spellboard books, this helps the secondary theme of the deck, which is cheap reaction spells. You want to be able to have these reactions in hand when the opportune moment arises, and the card draw facilitates that.  Additionally, Accelerate can provide opportunities for explosive turns where you maybe use two separate Fighting Spirits for a huge attack, or drop an Adept Duelist and a Time Hopper before attacking with your main action. 

Noah’s Shadow Target ability is a very good tool for dealing with problematic Ready Spells. Shutting off unit guard books like Summon Gilder, Butterfly Monk or Steadfast Guardian especially can really help keep those units off the board and be able to select your targets. Beefier units like Frostback Bears, Tidal Crabs or Indiglow Creepers are also excellent targets. 

It’s important to note that in the early game, you’ll want to be directing your attacks at units and not at the Phoenixborn.  This isn’t a Wide deck, even though it’s got a ton of small bodies. You want to thin your opponent out - as Fighting Spirit grows larger, even the smallest unit on your battlefield presents a huge threat. Your opponent will need to keep multiple different blockers up at all times later in the game, or risk you swinging through with Fighting Spirit and Stand Still, so use your units to attack and remove theirs, ideally only swinging at the Phoenixborn once there aren’t anymore good targets, or you can get a massive swing through.  This is especially true for the Time Hoppers, which can’t block. Try to find good times to attack something with them and threaten killing their unit with your little bunny to make them thing about using their Phoenixborn guard.  Also, Flash Strike is an amazing tool to swing a smaller unit into their big one, but then surprise them with Flash Strike to kill their big unit and save yours. 

The first five here is usually going to be the four Ready Spells and Gates Thrown Open, which will reset all your Ready Spells and let you use them again. That will cost 8 dice, giving you a die to use on Shadow Target and also one to either play a card that you draw if/when a Wishing Wing is destroyed, or to use a dice power.  If it’s a dice power, I recommend a Time dice power to put a token on a Time Hopper to help charge up Fighting Spirit when it dies, but be on the lookout for opportunities to boost up a Wishing swing as well to 2-3 attack and swing into something bigger.

name: Dual Duel Hope - Mist and Shadow…
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Styles:

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Control / Wide

Pressure: Mill / Bypass

This deck is one of the few times that I build something and think it can play in a couple of different styles / pressure points. It really speaks to how flexible Hope can be, and all of the different things that their unique, Void Pulse, does. 

This list aims to take advantage of Hope’s ability Duplicate to its highest degree, and planning to play more of a control / mill game, but potentially pivoting into a wide swing deck if it sees an opportunity. 

The Control + Mill plan is based on Shadow Hound combined with Hope’s Duplicate ability to keep the opponents mid-range and large units down and control their battlefield while, in the background, you’re spinning down their dice with Dreamlock Mage, Hollow, Dream Fracture and Void Pulse, forcing them to meditate a bunch and mill themselves, while you sit back with your Shifting Mist not needing to meditate much at all.  Duplicate also works great on Butterfly Monk to keep Hope’s life total strong and prolong the game while you focus on spindown. 

There’s also a decent amount of draw in the deck between Void Pulse, Iron Worker, Particle Shield and Mist Typhoon to try and draw into your extra Shadow Hound books and Dream Fractures to add additional control pressure. 

However, if your control is working well enough that you have an opening for a big swing, Raptor Herder is there to help make that wide swing bigger, and Duplicate is also great there on the Hatchling. Ice Trap and Void Pulse are nice bypass cards, taking out units at reaction speed. Keep an eye out for an opportunity to get big damage in with a swing, but your main focus should be control. 

I haven’t talked about False Demon. Demon is here for consistency, some additional control, and also self-clear in a pinch.  Hope’s Battlefield can get bogged down sometimes and you need an extra slot for Duplicate. Demon is great at pinging away one of your own exhausted little guys to get some space. And if you don’t need that, it’s a good body, a basic dice sink, and another good control tool so it fits in well. 

First five:  Shadow Hound, Butterfly, Demon, Dreamlock Mage, Flex, Duplicate. The flex can be any 1-die card - Shifting Mist / Raptor Herder / Ice Trap / Void Pulse.  You could also swap the Iron Worker in for the Dreamlock if you want to try to focus your Shadow Hound book quicker and aren’t afraid of Ice Trap in round 1.  I’d plan on starting Shifting Mist most of the time as the flex spot, but those other flex options are available if you think they’ll be a blowout round 1 play.

name: Dual Duel Echo - Purple Exhaustion Tricks
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Control

Pressure: Bypass

I’m going to admit right away that Echo isn’t a Phoenixborn I’m super comfortable with. That being said, I really like the different ways in which this deck can utilize his ability and his unique card, Chaos Gravity. 

This deck should be very good at exhausting opposing units and swinging past them WHEN YOU NEED TO. However, the great thing about exhausted units is that they can’t counter - use this fact to your advantage and still send your attacks into opposing units rather than all at the Phoenixborn. This will allow you to build up a commanding board presence and eventually push through. 

Knowing when and how to use Echo’s ability, Gravity Flux, is the key to making this deck sing. You’re equipped with many tricks to take advantage of it. False Demon and Fox Spirit both have abilities that come online when the opposing unit is exhausted.  You can use Gravity Flux as your side action, and then False Demon as a main to get a ping damage. Or attack with a Fox Spirit as a main to get its boost. Also, Gravity Flux can exhaust a Unit Guard like a Butterfly or Gilder, allowing you to attack the target you want.  You can also use it to exhaust the unit you want to attack, so it can’t counter you. Lastly, it’s always available to exhaust their only blocker so you can swing through.  Practice getting a feel for the best way to use it each round, since you only get one use of it and all of these tricks are great. 

Light bringer is even more exhaustion. Keep an eye out for when the opponent only had one fresh unit that they don’t want exhausted - that’s when you play your light bringer to force it to attack and exhaust. 

Another toolbox of allies here, but many of them excel at combining with Echo’s unique spell, Chaos Gravity.  To get the most out of this spell, you ideally need to have a good use for all 3 effects.  I find the second effect - moving an exhaustion - to be the toughest to use.  Oftentimes, I like to try to swing a couple bigger units and a small one like a Light Bringer early in the round. Then when you play Chaos Gravity, you can refresh one of them, and move a token from the other big guy to your light bringer, to refresh both of them.  The light bringer will be double-exhausted, but you can always ping it away with a demon later. 

Celestial Knight is difficult to kill, so it will usually survive an attack to be refreshed with Chaos Gravity.  Dreamlock is a great body for 2 dice, and you can use Restrict to spin down a snake die to avoid Golden Veil. Light Swordsman is great at attacking and not dying, which makes him perfect to refresh with Chaos Gravity.  Rose Fire Dancer is just a nice exhaustion spell that leaves a body waiting to be refreshed, and Shepherd is great to pull what you need. 

Meteor works here as a nice reset button, and it has extra synergy with Celestial Knight, who will survive it.  Chained Creations is a slept-on action spell that takes out a lot of good conjurations.  Steady Gaze furthers the exhaustion theme and allows you to move a token off of that unit with Chaos Gravity to exhaust something else if you can pull them off in the same round. If not, it’s just a great hard-removal spell. 

Fate Reflection for some protection against damage on your exhausted units so you can refresh them, and Figures for a surprise 1-die exhaust. 

First five is going to be the 3 books, Celestial Knight and a flex.  This can be any 2-dice spell or ally based on what you think you’ll face. Dreamlock, Chained Creations, Rose Fire, Chaos Gravity annd Steady Gaze are all good here.

name: Dual Duel Astrea - I’ve Got No Strings
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Control

Pressure: Burn

This deck focuses on cheap exhaustion effects and burn damage through Mark, Fire Archers, Final Cry, Puppets and Era’s End.  Even with just a Crypt Guard out, Era’s End exhausts a unit for one die, which is great.  Blood Chains and Astrea also can exhaust a unit for just one die.  Tire them out and burn them down!

Ready spells:  Blood Puppet is just another way to look at exhaustion - you’re exhausting a battlefield slot rather than exhausting a unit, plus it comes with extra burn damage. It might not go in the first 5 unless you’re against another small BF phoenixborn, but it can be great in round 2-3 to help choke their BF.  You get both turtles with Snapper and Turtle Guard - these are just good stat bodies for the dice, and Snapper clears out extra turtles to help with the 4 BF, and also self-triggers Final Cry.  Chant of Sacrifice is a techy way to clean up BF slots and also utilize Blood Puppeteers as more pseudo-exhaustion, plus again triggering Final Cry. 

Allies:  Crypt Guardian is the MVP here. The end of round exhaustion is amazing for BF choking, and can setup big top of round Mark of the Goddess shots to the opposing Phoenixborn.  Blood Puppeteer as mentioned above is another piece of choke tech, plus it can give you extra blockers in a pinch, and with Snapper and all of the other self-clear in here you don’t need to worry too much about a puppet ending up on your BF.  Fire Archer is just some more good burn damage, and the Ritualist gives you a round 1 body to start with your Chant of Sacrifice if you want it. 

Action spells:  a lot of these since you only have 4 BF, but all of them do multiple things. Mark of the Goddess doubles as a burn spell and a removal spell, and is amazing with Crypt Guardian. Blood Chains helps with battlefield clear, which is needed with the 4 BF, and also doubles to choke their board. Era’s End can be a burn spell with Puppets, an exhaustion / choke spell with Crypt Guardian, or a removal spell against Creepers.  Lastly, To Shadows can get rid of stuff exhausted by Beguile or otherwise, and can be self-clear in a pinch.  Note that when combined with Beguile, it’s even better than Frog Ping + Fester is, but be careful as you might want to keep that battlefield slot locked down until the end of the round. Side action To Shadows, main action Pass to end the round is one of the best feelings ever. 

Reactions: Final Cry is great burn reach, able to be self-triggered by Chant of Sacrifice, Snapper or Blood Chains. In this deck, it’s so easy to trigger yourself that it’s basically an action spell that doesn’t cost you an action. 

First five: a standard open would be Snapper, Turtle, Crypt Guardian, Ritualist, Blood Puppeteer/To Shadows/Blood Puppet book, Beguile.  That last spot is a bit of a flex - if you think a knight is coming, start the To Shadows. If it’s a small BF, you might want the book.

name: Dual Duel Xander - Life Will Find a Way
notes:

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Control

Pressure: Bypass

Xander is one of the most generically good Phoenixborn out there - he doesn’t have a ton of amazing things going for him, but his stats are excellent and his ability is nice to save him life vs using the ceremonial power.  To that end, we want to capitalize on his high life total and use his ability to fuel Cerasaurus Mount.  As that puts us into divine and nature, we’ll play some strong alterations to our midrange units. 

The spellboard is the crux of the deck here - it has our two strongest units in Bear and Cerasaurus that represent our wincon with their bypass, and the Butterfly to protect them and beef up Xander’s life total.  Cerasaurus is better here than in other decks because Xander can use his ability to always have ally fuel. 

Be careful how you play your Cerasaurus Mounts. It’s very powerful to be able to summon a Dino as a side action and then attack with your main action, but that means your ally has to survive a turn. Don’t try this if they have Frog dice showing, or against ceremonial at all due to Old Salt. However, that’s one place the Rayward Recruits (or Jungle Foragers if you swap them in) shine - with 2 life, they have a shot to survive a turn and setup that play. 

Speaking of the Allies, they work in conjunction with the spellboard cards to apply pressure. You have 8 good mount targets in Anchornaut, Raptor and Rayward Recruit. It’s important when playing Recruit to put the divine die on something else if you’re planning to mount it up. Ember Heart is good as well to reuse some of our alterations after a swing.  

EDIT: Jungle Forager might be a better card here than Rayward Recruit, allowing you to pull alterations into hand and that also gives you something to do with your extra die round 1. Credit to Fred for that suggestion. 

The alterations are all good at making good trades and pressuring damage on the PB if they’re on a terrifying Bear.  As a control deck though, you should be aiming to run your units into theirs unless you have nothing good to attack or the bypass ends the game. 

Molten Gold is a nice finisher that can be a removal spell in a pinch. Earthquake and Nature’s Wrath keep swarms under control with Earthquake doubling as spot removal. Also try to use these to open up battlefield slots on your board when you need to. 

Ice Trap can be first fived if you know it will trade up, otherwise it’s just solid mid-game removal. 

First five is probably the three books, two 1-cost Allies and a Frog dice power.  You can go any of the 1-cost guys, but I’d probably always have Raptor Herder.  Conversely if you’re confident there’s not an Ice Trap, you can go Herder + Pain Shaman.  Shaman isn’t a guy you want to mount often, but he comes with a bit bigger body and a built-in ping and a heal - you just want to make sure you don’t lose your Cerasauru for the round. But if you do, you can always pivot into Xander’s ability and replaying the ally, which isn’t the worst thing.

name: Dual Duel Victoria - Spin to Win
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Control

Pressure: Mill

Disclaimer 1: I won’t beat around the bush - in my opinion, there’s very little reason to play Victoria outside of just fun.  If you’re trying to win, Hope will do everything Victoria can but better. However, if you’re here for the chaos, then strap in!

Disclaimer 2: I’m looking forward to revamping this one once Vicky gets a new unique card that hopefully drives her stock up. 

Now, onto the chaos!  When looking at Victoria, I see two potential things that she can do better than other Phoenixborn: avoid reactions when they have more than 2 power dice showing, and activate Dream Fracture when they have more than 2 power dice showing. That’s about it.  I tried to lean into those when constructing this list.  The idea here is to just spin down all the dice - you need to force them to meditate a lot of cards while you put up a wall, and slowly burn them out with Dream Fracture and eventual fatigue damage.  This plays like a mill deck and not a burn deck because Dream Fracture just isn’t enough to get you there on its own, so you’ll need to fatigue them out. 

The Shadow Hound and Mist Spirit books are control tools against midrange and swarm units respectively.  Abundance helps focus your books and threaten your reactions.  Dream Fracture is the eventual wincon of the deck. Lastly, Keepsake has great synergy in this deck and, once setup, can be a good deterrent for knights and other big units to be played, as Vicky can always just Surprise + pop Keepsake to not only kill a big threat, but probably avoid Golden Veil or Fate Reflection thanks to Surprise spinning down dice. 

Mill decks tend to want healing, and illusion / sympathy has basically none of that, so Channel Magic makes it in. The draw and spin up are also helpful in a long game. Gates is a first 5 card, but also great later game as a spindown card to get more uses out of Fracture and Abundance, and more Misties if you need them.  Steady Gaze is a very underrated card that needs more play and, with 10 illusion dice, it makes sense here. Spin down the snake dice and gaze down those big threats. 

I’m running 1 Copycat here, just for a surprise usage or maybe a first 5 against a PB with a nasty action spell. Particle Shield and Figures in the Fog are great answers though to pinging away your misties and exhausted hounds while drawing more cards, and Figures is an excellent pseudo-removal spell to deal with particularly frustrating units like Sonic Swordsman if you can’t Keepsake or Gaze them.  The Shadow Guards are just a couple more surprise answers to midrange units. 

The normal first five here is probably Abundance, Fracture, Hound, Mist Spirit, Gates. Don’t plan to use Surprise - either make more mist spirits or play something you draw with abundance. Steady Gaze and Copycat can slide in for Gates or Fracture if you think they’ll help.

name: Dual Duelling Odette - Big Butts… of Virtue
notes:
This is a deck in my Dual Duel series. These decks are designed for newer players to get into deckbuilding and understand how more competitive Ashes decks work while sticking to just 2 colors and straightforward lines of play.

Each deck will be laid out defining the Style I’ve built the deck in that helps point towards how to pilot it, and the Pressure Tactic the deck uses to force the game to a conclusion. I believe that all Ashes decks should be built with these two things in mind, and pilots should understand them going into a game.

Here’s a breakdown of my different Styles and Pressure Tactics I believe that most Ashes decks can be divided into these buckets:

Styles:

Tall: Create one or two really big units and protect them until they’re ready to strike or use them to protect your Phoenixborn.

Wide: Create many small, efficient units to overwhelm your opponents battlefield and potentially attack around their blockers to hit the Phoenixborn.

Control: Focus on limiting the opponent’s options and keeping opponent’s units down either by continually destroying them with spells or unit attacks, or by continually exhausting them.

Pressure Tactics:

Bypass: Swinging past your opponent’s units to damage the Phoenixborn. This can be done by giving your units evasion so they cannot be blocked, or by destroying or exhausting all of your opponents units to allow yours to swing through.

Burn: Deal damage to the opposing Phoenixborn using spells or abilities that directly deal damage to or place wounds on a Phoenixborn.

Mill: Focus on removing cards from the opponent’s deck either by discarding them from the deck directly, forcing the opponent to draw them, or manipulating the opponents dice to make them meditate more and discard their own cards to do it. This forces the opponent into fatigue faster.

—————————————————————

Style: Control

Pressure: Bypass

This deck attempts to overwhelm the battlefield by flooding life into it that’s accompanied by a ton of ping damage and removal, eventually swinging through the open hole. 

Odette’s Enter the Fray ability lends itself very well to this - the power of being able to deal 2 damage for no dice can’t be overstated. It costs you PB life, but you need to use that life as a resource. Also, you have Butterfly Monk and Phoenix Attendant to replenish that resource. 

This deck also actively tries to avoid Ice Trap, by having only 1x Ritualist and Butterfly Monks as eligible targets, and neither of those really feels good to spend an Ice Trap on. 

Frostback Bear provides a bit of natural bypass to the PB, but this should be used sparingly. Bear is better here as a control tool - use its good stat line to try to make favorable trades and avoid unit guards with Terrifying.  Remember you’re a control deck:  your win condition isn’t swinging past the blockers - it’s removing them and then swinging when the pathway is clear. 

The ally suite is designed to offer both high life and removal with each play.  Even Phoenix Attendant can be combined with Chant of Transfusion to generate removal. 

Blood Chains and Sword of Virtue both do multiple things with one card as well - they’re hard removal that gets around armor and alterations, which are very popular right now. They can also both help with managing Odette’s small battlefield by either destroying or refreshing exhausted units. Clashing Tempers is just a fantastic card in lots of different situations, and fits seamlessly into a deck that wants to pump out life and damage at the same time, as it does both of those in one card.  Wrath (along with Tempers) can help get the board back under control if you start getting outnumbered. Lastly, Ice Trap is just almost a must in this day and age, and it represents even more removal that isn’t damage-based. 

First Five always includes Bear, Butterfly and Ritualist to grab Chant of Transfusion. From there, you want either Old Salt or a Hammer Knight, and then probably either Ice Trap, Root Armor for the Hammer Knight, or maybe Nature’s Wrath if you’re against a sympathy Tristan or a sympathy / ceremonial Hope that might try to swarm you. If you start Old Salt and a 1-die spell, use a Frog dice power as well in round 1.
